quizzes.question: Which two options do you need to write and run C++ programs?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Getting the Tools[/h1]

You can run, save, and share your C++ codes on our [b]Code Playground[/b], without installing any additional software.
[note]Reference this lesson if you need to install the software on your computer. [/note]
You need both of the following components to build C++ programs.
1. [b]Integrated Development Environment (IDE)[/b]: Provides tools for writing source code. Any text editor can be used as an IDE.
2. [b]Compiler[/b]: Compiles source code into the final executable program. There are a number of C++ compilers available. The most frequently used and free available compiler is the [b]GNU C/C++[/b] compiler.

Various C++ IDEs and compilers are available. We'll use a free tool called [b]Code::Blocks[/b], which includes both an IDE and a compiler, and is available for Windows, Linux and MacOS.
To download Code::Blocks, go to http://www.codeblocks.org/, Click the [b]Downloads [/b]link, and choose "[b]Download the binary release[/b]".
Choose your OS and download the setup file, which includes the C++ compiler (For Windows, it's the one with [b]mingw [/b]in the name).
[note]Make sure to install the version that includes the [b]compiler[/b].[/note]

quizzes.question: Which of the following is a C++ compiler?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Getting the Tools[/h1]

To create a project, open Code::Blocks and click "[b]Create a new project[/b]" (or File->New->Project).
This will open a dialog of project templates. Choose [b]Console application [/b]and click [b]Go[/b]. [img id="2420" width="100%"]
Go through the wizard, making sure that C++ is selected as the language.
Give your project a name and specify a folder to save it to. [img id="2419" width="100%"]
Make sure the [b]Compiler [/b]is selected, and click [b]Finish[/b].
[b]GNU GCC[/b] is one of the popular compilers available for Code::Blocks.
On the left sidebar, expand [b]Sources[/b]. You'll see your project, along with its source files. Code::Blocks automatically created a [b]main.cpp[/b] file that includes a basic Hello World program (C++ source files have .cpp, .cp or .c extensions).[img id="2417" width="100%"]
Click on the "[b]Build and Run[/b]" icon in the toolbar to compile and run the program.[img id="2416" width="70%"]
A [b]console window[/b] will open and display program output. [img id="2418" width="100%"]
Congratulations! You just compiled and ran your first C++ program!
[note]You can run, save, and share your C++ codes on our [b]Code Playground[/b], without installing any additional software.
Reference this lesson if you need to install the software on your computer. [/note]
